newsitem.title: UK: TENNIS-PHILIPPOUSSIS WINS SERVE DUEL WITH IVANISEVIC.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-PHILIPPOUSSIS WINS SERVE DUEL WITH IVANISEVIC.

text.p: Australian Mark Philippoussis, the fastest server on the circuit, won the London grass court title on Sunday with a thumping 7-5 6-3 victory over fellow big-hitter Goran Ivanisevic.
The 20-year-old from Melbourne, who holds the record of 229 kph for the fastest serve ever measured, banged down 15 aces in an almost error-free display of power tennis.
There were only two break points in the match - in the 12th game of the first set and the eighth of the second and Philippoussis, playing his most consistent tennis of the week, made no mistake.

Ivanisevic, who said he was concentrating too much on returning his opponent's serve and not enough on his own game, made a couple of volleying errors in the first set and played two loose shots in the second to lose the match.
"I played two bad service games," the world number three said. "He was serving really well."
Ivanisevic, like Philippoussis, a lofty 1.94 metres tall, hit 12 aces in the match which produced only a handful of rallies longer than four shots.

The longest exchange happened after a frustrated Ivanisevic offered his racket to ball girl Amy Kavanagh at 3-3 in the second set. Philippoussis played a gentle rally of 17 shots with the girl before gallantly losing the point.
The result gives the Australian, ranked 19th going into the tournament, his third title of the year after Scottsdale and Munich and a boost before Wimbledon starts on June 23.
Philippoussis, nicknamed Scud because of his ferocious serve, said he had matured over the past year.
"Every year I'm a better player, everything is coming together and I say to myself there is nothing I can't win now," he said.
"I've been working on my movement, which is important on grass, where the ball goes so fast."
Philippoussis who has now won a tournament on every surface -- clay, indoor, cement and grass -- began the match as he intended to go on, with three successive aces.
The encounter looked certain to be heading for a tie-break without a single deuce or break point until the 12th game, when Ivanisevic put two volleys long to hand the Australian the set.
Philippoussis's only wobble came after the ball-girl incident when at 40-0 up he double faulted and netted an easy volley. But he came back with an ace to take the game.
At 3-4 down, Ivanisevic lost his serve after Philippoussis produced two lovely passes and the Croat put a shot long.
Philippoussis then served out to 15 for the match.
"I did nothing wrong this week. I'm really looking forward to Wimbledon now," the Australian, the first to win at Queen's since Tony Roche in 1978, said.
